metadata.title: New polymer-bound Rh carbonyl cluster catalysts containing two functional ligands for hydrohydroxymethylation of olefins

accepted January 8, 1992) The chemistry of heterogenization of metal cluster complexes using organic and inorganic polymers has attracted much interest because new methods of preparation of metal catalysts have been developed and it is expected that unique catalysis due to interactions with the polymer surface will occur [ 1 ]. We have already reported that homogeneous Rh carbonyl cluster complexes showed high catalytic activities for deoxygenation of various N-O bonds, reduction of carbonyl compounds and hydrohydroxymethylation of olefins under CO and H20 [2-4]. Our Rh catalyst systems need diamines as an additive and alkoxyethanol as a solvent to attain high catalytic activities. Using polystyrene supports, we can obtain novel heterogenized complexes consisting of three components: Rh clusters, diamines and alcohols. Such supported complexes show a high catalytic activity for hydrohydroxy- / 2CO/H20 H I CO/H20 H I /C=C` o. - i -i-CHO -C-C-CHZOH +2COz +CO2 methylation of olefins. Although various kinds of polymer supports have been extensively developed, little is known about polymer-bound metal complex catalysts having two functional ligands [5-9]. Preparation of bifunctionalized polystyrenes is shown in Scheme 1. Chloromethylpolystyrene (Cl 22.11%) was reacted with N,N-dimethyl-1,3propanediamine to give an aminated polymer (I, N 9.12%, Cl 7.11 %). Further, treatment of the remaining chloromethyl moieties of I with ethyleneglycol or glycerol afforded the bifunctionalized polymers containing amino and hydroxyl groups (II, N 7.61%, CI 0.64% and III, N 7.82%, CI 0.62%), respectively. The polymer (IV, N 7.80%, Cl 0.65%) with protection against hydroxyl groups was also obtained by a similar treatment with 2-ethoxyethanol. A typical reaction catalyzed by rhodium complexes of these polymers is the hydrohydroxymethylation of 1-butene. A stainless steel autoclave containing "`Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/92/$5.00 0 1992 - Elsevier Sequoia. TABLE 1 Reaction of 1-butene using CO and HZO in the presence of various aminated polymers and TMPDA' Solvent Yield of C-5 alcohols (9o, 1/b) Polymer (I) (1I) (HU (IV) TODA EtOH 64 (1.70) 63 (2.17) 73 (2.29) 62 (2.48) 31 (2.48) THF 41 (1.74) 60 (1.62) 83 (1.68) 46 (2.17) 27 (2.72) benzene 8 (1.89) 55 (1.29) 79 (1.28) 5 (3.18) 8 (3.04) "Rho(CO)18 0.05 mmol, 1-butene 5 mmol, polymer 0.8 mg-atom of N, solvent 4 ml, HZO 0.72 ml, P(CO)=20 atm, 80 C, 24 h. Yields are based on 1-butene used and 1/b indicates product ratio between pentanol and 2methyl-l-butanol. `TMPDA 5 mmol, 5 h. Rhe(CO)lg and one of the aminated polymers (I-M was evacuated and flushed three times with CO. 1-Butene, H20 and solvent were added. The reaction was carried out with stirring under 20 atm of CO. Or the reaction, the dark green polymer-bound Rh complex could be easily removed by filtration. The liquid phase was analyzed by GLC. The products from these hydrohydroxymethylation reactions of 1-butene, catalyzed by complexes of the above aminated polymers (I-M in various solvents, are shown in Table 1. Also shown are the results obtained by employing the corresponding homogeneous system using N,N,N',N'-tetra- L29 methyl-1,3-propanediamine (TMPDA). Pentanol and 2-methyl-l-butanol are the main products, accompanied by small amounts of pentanal and 2-methyl1-butanal. Since the Rh cluster system is an effective catalyst for reduction of aldehyde compounds [3 ], the hydroformylation products were easily reduced to the corresponding C-5 alcohols under the reaction conditions. In all solvents, use of aminated polymer III, with two hydroxyl groups-per styrene unit, gives the highest yield of the C-5 alcohols among all the aminated polymers (I-Ifs. Increasing hydroxyl group concentration in aminated polymers increases the yield of the alcohols; in benzene, a hydrophobic solvent, aminated polymers of I and IV without hydroxyl groups showed extremely low catalytic activities for the hydrohydroxymethylation. Also, the homogeneous TMPDA system yielded far smaller amounts of hydrohydroxymethylation products, compared with those in THF and EtOH solvent. Introduction of hydroxyl groups into the polymers leads to appearance of a new catalyst function, the formation of a `triphase system' [ 10 ] for the olefin hydrohydroxymethylation. Similar phenomena were also observed in the cases of 1- and 2-octenes. Re-use of the recovered polymer-bound Rh carbonyl complex gave a yield of the alcohols similar to that of the fresh catalyst (73 vs. 70% in EtOH).* Chini et al. have reported that treatment of [Rhe(CO)1bH]- anion with ethylene and propylene gave Rhg(CO)1b-acyl complex [ 12 ]. Presumably, an active species in hydroformylation might be the [Rhs(CO)16H]- anion. A similar metal cluster-catalyzed hydroformylation has been proposed in the case of [Ru3(CO)11H]- [13]. Reduction of pentanal with the aminated polymer-bound Rhg complex gave pentanol in quantitative yield under the above reaction conditions. Therefore, a common active Rh species might participate in both hydroformylation and reduction. Laine has reported the homogeneous hydrohydroxymethylation of olefins using Rhs(CO)18 and KOH under high CO pressures [14]. *Turnovers (mol of alcohols/mol of Rho(CO),o) corresponding to these 73 and 7096 yields are 73 and 70, respectively. L30 The main functions of the dianlino groups in the polymers are (1) generation of OH- in aqueous media to yield an active Rh cluster anion species, (2) stabilization and heterogenization of the Rh cluster anions by forming ion-pairs, and (3) control for the reaction course through coordination of an amino moiety to Rh clusters [ 15 ] . H20 plays an important role in stabilization of the Rh active species and provides the hydrogen source for alcohol formation from olefins. Introduction of hydroxyl groups into the aminated polymers increases hydrophilicity around active Rh cluster centers, which also contributes to the stabilization of active Rh carbonyl cluster anions. Use of polymers with two functional groups offers not only increased catalytic activities, but also a simplification of the work-up procedure in the above organic reactions using aqueous media.
